author: Laura Tingle
title: ASIO: the Soviet mole cliffhanger
text:
"ASIO came to be seen in the eyes of protesters and other observers as the tool of a conservative government." Fairfax Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Laura Tingle The involvement of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation in the downfall of the Whitlam government, and its activities during the anti-Vietnam War protest era have long been the subject of conspiracy theories.
Sadly, the second volume of the just released The Protest Years: The Official History of ASIO 1963-1975 paints a slightly less colourful portrait of our domestic spy agency in this tumultuous period of history, dismissing suggestions that it acted on behalf of the US government against Whitlam, but documenting a complete misreading of the threat of the anti-war movement, which it pursued with an often bumbling approach.
Even without the conspiracy theories being validated, the book, by John Blaxland of the ANU's Strategic and Defence Studies Centre, provides a compelling account of ASIO's activities – glorious and otherwise – from the end of the Menzies era through to Whitlam's dismissal.
It is not an uncritical book, noting, for example, failures in both the agency and executive government in maintaining a proper relationship.
Launching the book on Friday, Attorney-General George Brandis noted that Dr Blaxland appeared "not entirely satisfied" with ASIO's response to the rise of anti-war movement, "in particular, its closeness to the government of the day and the extent of its involvement in what were, very often, more properly matters of domestic politics than national security".
In what Senator Brandis said was an "admirably balanced judgement", Dr Blaxland says "it is easy to cast aspersions on ASIO for its focus on the protest movement, but it was not an independent actor, and was not working without government sanction".
Failure to demand enough accountability "Meeting the government's requirement [to conduct surveillance], ASIO gained a thorough knowledge of the activities of the protesters. The government failed to demand enough from ASIO in terms of accountability, but the government wished to be kept informed and ASIO ensured it was," the book says.
 "ASIO came to be seen in the eyes of protesters and other observers as the tool of a conservative government, reaffirming views held since the Petrov defection in 1954. Not surprisingly, therefore, when a change of government occurred at the end of 1972, ASIO would be in for a shock."
The difficult relationship with the Whitlam government comprises much of the book, but Dr Blaxland also launched the volume at ASIO headquarters in Canberra on Friday with a cliffhanger: suggesting the third and final volume of the history to be released next year would reveal that the agency had been "penetrated" by the Soviet Union or an eastern bloc country.
Paranoia about a Soviet mole had been strong in the 1960s and 1970s – which the second volume covers, leading to the then director-general, Brigadier Charles Spry setting up a special unit to pursue possible infiltrators.
While concern about espionage and subversion is now often dismissed in the post-Cold War era, Dr Blaxland says the evidence is "compelling that the Soviet Union and its Eastern bloc proxies were actively engaged in espionage in Australia".
"Their efforts were multifaceted, enduring and relentless … there remained a variety of … Trotskyist or socialist splinter groups [that] retained a dogged fixation in terms of rhetoric and apparent intention, if not in capability, on the violent overthrow of Australia's parliamentary democratic system."
